Award.AwardTitle: Interfaces and Related Losses in PEM Fuel Cells: Theoretical and Experimental Studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1066623 PI Kumbur

The objective of this work is to define a scientific framework that enables detailed assessment of the interfacial morphology and interfacial transport mechanisms on the of the polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEFCs). The PIs hypothesize that a major reason for many shortcomings of current model is the treatment of the interface as an infinitely thin layer, having perfect contact and homogenous properties. Preliminary work by PIs demonstrates that the micro-porous layer (MPL) and catalyst layer (CL) surfaces are not smooth; instead they exhibit surface irregularities, such as elongated surface cracks, holes, and dents. These surface features result in imperfect interfaces, which promote performance loss an. Compelling evidence suggests that interfacial regions are of importance in fuel-cell performance, but a fundamental understanding of the role of these critical regions is still lacking. The PIs will address this issue and perform a verification of the impact of the interface on the performance and durability of PEFCs. To achieve this, the PIs will carry out a combined experimental and computational plan, including: 1) ex-situ and in-situ measurements of a broad range of interfacial transport properties and water retention characteristics using advanced diagnostic tools and neutron imaging, 2) digital characterization of the bonded interface structure through a combined optical profilometry and dual-beam focused ion-beam scanning electron microscope study, 3) development of a validated interfacial contact model ( adapting well-established frameworks from tribology) to create a set of cloned virtual MPL/CL interface structures under compression, and 4) using these virtual interfaces, develop multi-scale transport and performance models to describe the impact of these interface regions on the mass, thermal and electrical transport characteristics of PEFCs.
Intellectual Merit: This approach will enable higher fidelity modeling capability with realistic interfacial morphology and interfacial transport. This project will not only have a substantial impact on the engineering of novel materials for high performance, but also will provide significant guidance for durability studies. The proposed methodology also has a strong transformative nature as it will bring a new perspective to approach the interface related performance and durability issues in PEFCs and other types of fuel cells. The proposed methodology for characterizing the interface will be transformable to other fields, as it can be further extended into other electrochemical systems (e.g., Li-ion and other batteries) to help us address similar fundamental gaps.
Broader Impact: Specific activities will include: i) training of graduate and undergraduate students in multidisciplinary engineering fields, ii) formation of a yearly graduate student exchange between labs at Drexel and Carnegie Mellon (CMU), iii) development of new instructional materials for fuel cell courses taught at Drexel and CMU, iv) active recruitment and training of women and underrepresented minority engineers by leveraging the established programs (REU, IGERT, GAANN, LSAMP) at Drexel and CMU, v) training of local high school students through Drexel Mentorship Program, vi) hosting local high school teachers through Drexel-Penn NanoRET program to develop educational modules related to alternative energy, vii) semi-annual workshops for high school teachers as a part of the ?What is Engineering? program at CMU, and viii) presentation of results in publications and PIs? websites for broader dissemination.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The adverse effects of fossil fuels are pushing the world to look for new energy resources and devices. Among the new technologies, polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs) are one of the promising energy conversion systems, which hold great potential due to their high operating efficiency. PEFCs convert chemical energy of a fuel and oxidizer directly into electrical energy, through an electrochemical reaction. In addition to electricity, water and heat are generated as environmentally friendly byproducts. PEFCs have high power density and are easily scalable, making them viable for a wide range of applications.

        PEFCs consist of two sides, anode and cathode, and a polymer membrane which separates these two sides. Hydrogen is used as fuel and enters the cell through the anode flow channels. Similarly, oxygen, which is the oxidizer, flows through the cathode side flow channels. Hydrogen and oxygen diffuse through the porous diffusion media components at the anode and cathode side, respectively and participate in an electrochemical reaction at the anode and cathode catalyst layers. As a result of the electrochemical reactions, water is generated inside the cell. Although water is a clean and environmentally friendly product, it may have severe effect on the components and the system operation. For instance, the excess amount of water can block the pores of the diffusion media, hindering the reactant transport, which would lead to decreased system performance. Therefore for enhanced performance, generated water inside the cell needs to be properly removed from the system.

While a good number of studies regarding water management in PEFCs have been performed at the component and system level, little is understood or known regarding the effects of interface between the components on the performance of PEFCs. In this project, our main hypothesis was that interfaces between components may hold a good amount of water which may impede the reactant transport. Motivated by this, the overall goal of this project was to understand and quantify the effects of the interfaces on the water management and performance of PEFCs.  To accomplish this goal, we have conducted experimental and computational studies in order to understand and quantify the role of the interfaces between the components on water distribution and retention inside the cell. Then this understanding was linked to the changes in system performance with respect to water content in the cell.

      Our studies confirmed our hypothesis that the interfaces within components can affect the water distribution inside the cell. Depending upon the operating condition, the water storage at the interfacial voids can lead to considerably high saturation in the diffusion media. As a result, reactant transport can be impeded which leads to a decrease in the PEFC performance. Our studies also indicate that one potential approach to minimize the interfacial water storage is engineering the surface of the components with desired features for effective water removal. The idea behind this approach is that by creating pathways (e.g., microchannel), it is possible to remove water from the interfaces easily due to the lower capillary forces at these modified features. However, it is important to note that identification of such surface modification requires additional optimization studies based on the target operating conditions and materials used in these systems. In summary, the findings of this project underline the importance of proper tailoring of interfaces to achieve an effective water management, suggesting that the interfaces should be carefully considered and studied before making any system design for these low temperature fuel cells.


Last Modified:...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The adverse effects of fossil fuels are pushing the world to look for new energy resources and devices. Among the new technologies, polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs) are one of the promising energy conversion systems, which hold great potential due to their high operating efficiency. PEFCs convert chemical energy of a fuel and oxidizer directly into electrical energy, through an electrochemical reaction. In addition to electricity, water and heat are generated as environmentally friendly byproducts. PEFCs have high power density and are easily scalable, making them viable for a wide range of applications. PEFCs consist of two sides, anode and cathode, and a polymer membrane which separates these two sides. Hydrogen is used as fuel and enters the cell through the anode flow channels. Similarly, oxygen, which is the oxidizer, flows through the cathode side flow channels. Hydrogen and oxygen diffuse through the porous diffusion media components at the anode and cathode side, respectively and participate in an electrochemical reaction at the anode and cathode catalyst layers. As a result of the electrochemical reactions, water is generated inside the cell. Although water is a clean and environmentally friendly product, it may have severe effect on the components and the system operation. For instance, the excess amount of water can block the pores of the diffusion media, hindering the reactant transport, which would lead to decreased system performance. Therefore for enhanced performance, generated water inside the cell needs to be properly removed from the system. While a good number of studies regarding water management in PEFCs have been performed at the component and system level, little is understood or known regarding the effects of interface between the components on the performance of PEFCs. In this project, our main hypothesis was that interfaces between components may hold a good amount of water which may impede the reactant transport. Motivated by this, the overall goal of this project was to understand and quantify the effects of the interfaces on the water management and performance of PEFCs. To accomplish this goal, we have conducted experimental and computational studies in order to understand and quantify the role of the interfaces between the components on water distribution and retention inside the cell. Then this understanding was linked to the changes in system performance with respect to water content in the cell. Our studies confirmed our hypothesis that the interfaces within components can affect the water distribution inside the cell. Depending upon the operating condition, the water storage at the interfacial voids can lead to considerably high saturation in the diffusion media. As a result, reactant transport can be impeded which leads to a decrease in the PEFC performance. Our studies also indicate that one potential approach to minimize the interfacial water storage is engineering the surface of the components with desired features for effective water removal. The idea behind this approach is that by creating pathways (e.g., microchannel), it is possible to remove water from the interfaces easily due to the lower capillary forces at these modified features. However, it is important to note that identification of such surface modification requires additional optimization studies based on the target operating conditions and materials used in these systems. In summary, the findings of this project underline the importance of proper tailoring of interfaces to achieve an effective water management, suggesting that the interfaces should be carefully considered and studied before making any system design for these low temperature fuel cells.
